content.description:
Start SITTING with a left hand crimp and a positive right hand pinch. Compress up the arete and the crack, leading to a slopey crux near the end. It has incredible rock. 

  Featured at the 1:51 mark in this vid 

vimeo.com/155927321
content.protection: 3 pads and a spotter. The landing is weird
content.location: This is 50 feet above the Big 45. See directions under that climb.

content.description:
This is a project.... All the moves have gone, and it seems like it will be in the V12 or V13 ish range when completed, but who knows? 

  Start sitting matched on a flat jug, and do a hard four move sequence into the obvious quartz block. From the block, try either crossing to a slopey crimp and try to static the rail, or do some kind of dynamic move to the rail. Once you stick the rail, V2 climbing leads to an easy mantle. Get after it!
content.protection: 3 or so pads and a spotter if you're trying to send, maybe 2 if you're working the moves.
content.location: From the Riverblock parking lot, walk across the bridge and take a left onto an obvious trail. Follow the trail downstream for 25-30 minutes. At around the 25 minute mark, you will walk through a large grove of pine trees. A couple minutes into the grove, you will see a giant boulder 200ish feet up the hill. The project climbs the center of the steep face.

content.description: Start sitting with a low left hand on the left arete and a right hand around the corner on a sloper. Compress up the narrow feature, and top out around the right arete.
content.location: Walk up and left around One Sunday Morning. It's pretty much right on top of it. 2 mins from the big 45 project . -see directions for the big 45 project

content.description: The area turd! On the backside of the Big 45, start sitting under the low roof on two very poor crimps with a poor heel toe cam in. Do a big move to a slopey pinch at the lip, and then flip your right hand into a shark's tooth spike in order to move your feet out left. Match the lip, and finish up some good holds.
content.location: It is on the back side of the Big 45. -see directions for the big 45 project

content.description: Start on a jug at chest height, and climb up the massive arete. After 8 or so easy moves, there is a crux hop to an obvious spike. Once established here, rock around the arete to some crimps on the slab...or be a boss and follow the lip all the way to the top.
content.protection: At least a few big pads and an active spotter.
content.location: From the Big 45, walk up the hill to the trail, and follow it for 500 feet or so. Before you come to a field, cut uphill for 300 feet or so until you hit the cliff ban. It's right there.  -see directions for the big 45 project

content.description: This climb starts on a horizontal brick pinch with a low foot out right. Compress up the lip over an unpadable but soft landing of loose dirt. It has quality rock.
content.location: This ascends the left arete of the Big 45 Boulder. -see directions for the big 45 project

content.description: Start on the flat jug as for the big 45 project, climb into okonsha via a big cross over with a heel hook.
content.location: left arete of the Big 45 boulder

content.description:
Start standing on the edge of the landing zone, and get onto the wall by jumping and catching the sloping lip with your right, while compressing the flat undercling rail with your left and hold a freaky swing. Match the lip, and continue up and left to an easy mantle. 

  Featured at the 1:12 mark in this video 

vimeo.com/155927321
content.location: This ascends the right arete of the Big 45 Boulder. -see directions for the big 45 project

content.description: Big 45 is a steep boulder with a handful of problems.
